name: Scalability
description: The ability of a system to accommodate an increasing number of elements, process growing volumes of work gracefully and where capacity can be expanded.

components.name: Infrastructure
components.definition: The infrastructure has scaling criteria. How this is managed will depend on a level of maturity.

criteria.name: Applications or infrastructure are scaled manually and success depends upon the skills of key people.
Success of scalability requirement gathering, designing, development, and acquisition depends entirely upon the skills of a small number of individuals.

Initial attempts by individual teams to gather scalability requirements in a consistent way.  Categories of scalability requirements and metrics start being adopted - e.g. transaction growth rates (with proxies used where appropriate such as GDP or population growth), time required to scale application or infrastructure by certain percentage points, etc.

Consistent group-wide processes for gathering scalability requirements are adopted.  Categories of scalability requirements and metrics start being adopted - e.g. transaction growth rates (with proxies used where appropriate such as GDP or population growth), time required to scale application or infrastructure by certain percentage points, etc.
Some basic tools are adopted by individuals - e.g. Excel for KPI tracking, etc.

Initial attempts to adopt tools to design, implement, and monitor scalability are adopted.  Examples include test environments, test tools, containerisation frameworks, vendor scalability tools, and monitoring tools.
Standard tools to design, implement, and monitor scalability are adopted. Examples include test environments, test tools, containerisation frameworks, vendor scalability tools, and monitoring tools.
Some roles may be defined by individual contributors.
Individual teams are defining roles with respect to scalability requirements, design, development, deployment, and operations.
Roles are defined with respect to scalability requirements, design, development, deployment, and operations.
Initial attempts made to establish design goals and principles for scaling by individual teams.
Scalability design goals and principles are adopted group-wide and followed.
Initial attempts at performing scalability testing as part of the release - for example, CI and CD pipeline for custom software.
Scalability testing is performed in a consistent way throughout the group.
Standards for consistent operational processes with respect to scalability are emerging.  These may include monitoring of auto-scaling decisions, etc.
Consistent operational processes with respect to scalability are followed. These may include monitoring of auto-scaling decisions, etc.
Some scalability metrics are collected by individual contributors at their own initiative.
Some metrics may be defined by individual teams, but are not consistently collected.
Some metrics may be defined, but are not consistently collected.
Scalability metrics are collected and reported on regularly. Examples may include cost of scaling up or down, time to scale by certain percentage points, etc.
Scalability metrics are fed back into the SDLC or vendor processes to improve availability.
Scalability metrics are defined and collected consistently and improvement goals are set.

questions.definition: What are your primary objectives, guidelines and goals in regard to scalability? Are they aligned with the rest of the organisation (e.g ARC Tiers)?

How is the application/service architected to enable scalability? 
a.	Do you directly control your supporting infrastructure (hardware, servers, networking equipment)? Who supports it? Who provisions it?
Do you have any roles formally defined in your team to consider scalability requirements? Roles could be assigned to document, design, test and/or measure scalability over time

How are you testing scalability in SS, SSB, HSM and Cassandra? Does this testing include upstream and/or downstream systems or is it run in isolation?
a.	Note: this is distinct from performance testing. That is â€“ how do you test your system's ability to respond to and cope with changes in demand. Both short-term (I.e. sudden spikes) and longer-term trends.
Are there any scalability features (e.g auto-scaling) across components that you can apply?
Are you utilising any tools, frameworks and libraries specifically for responding to scalability events (e.g. thresholds crossed)? (covering design, test and execution)
Do you have any metrics and reports collected in relation to scalability and capacity?
Are there any improvement goals defined around scalability, with respect to the above metrics?
